BIOS767
Notes
This is a new module written for the MSc Precision Medicine programme. It is due to commence in September 2025.

Overview

Overview
This is a key module for students on the MSc Precision Medicine programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBiolSci and MRes students interested in core and novel aspects of Precision Medicine. The module includes research-connected lectures and seminars delivered by leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers from the pharmaceutical industry and regulatory agencies. Topics include pharmacogenomics (discovery and implementation), biomarkers and omics technologies for personalised medicine, precision drug development and advances in individualised drugs. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively. The first will be a written report and the second a short "elevator pitch"-style oral presentation. Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team.
Educational Aims
This module will provide students with a comprehensive understanding of core, novel and emerging concepts on precision medicine. The specific aims are to:

Familiarise students with the concepts of precision medicine from both a pharmaceutical development and clinical perspective.

Make students aware of technological advances in precision medicine and how they can improve patients outcomes.

Equip students with the knowledge and skills to enable critical appraisal of established and novel approaches to precision medicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This key module in the MSc Precision Medicine programme (but optional for other MSc programmes) brings together core and novel aspects of personalised therapeutic approaches in the context of clinical implementation and drug discovery and development. Topics include , pharmacogenomics, biomarkers, omics application to precision medicine, companion diagnostics and drug development and emerging personalised drug modalities. This builds on local research strengths (e.g. Wolfson Centre for Personalised medicine and Centre for Drug Safety Science) and strong links with the pharmaceutical industry, health service providers and regulatory agencies. Indeed, this module provides a unique opportunity to learn about the industry pipeline for developing precision medicine products in its entirety. The module includes research connected lectures and seminars, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating reports (one written, one oral) on topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus will cover the following topics:

Precision Medicine- Industry Perspective
Diagnostic Development
Regulatory Approval of Diagnostics
Companion Diagnostics
What is companion diagnostic?
Drug/Dx co-development
Case Studies of CDx
Strategy and planning for Drug/Dx co-development
Assessing value of a biomarker

Precision Healthcare- Clinical Perspective
Discovery Pharmacogenomics and technologies
Drug Safety
Drug Efficacy/ pharmacodynamics
Clinical Implementation
Health Economics
Ethical Considerations
PGx in Drug Discovery and drug repurposing

Precision Medicine- Current and Future Perspectives
Individualised Drug Therapies
Multi-omics approaches in precision medicine
Digital Health- what is it?
Sensors/ digital diagnostics
Artificial intelligence and machine learning in precision medicine
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be 30 hours of scheduled learning time, comprising a combination of lectures and seminars. Lectures will be delivered by University staff with research expertise in specific topics. Seminars will be delivered by external experts from the pharmaceutical industry or healthcare sector. In both cases, students may be asked to apply their knowledge during the completion of in-session tasks and discussion of the outcomes.

Independent learning time will be used to support the scheduled directed learning, including through independent reading of materials related to each of the lectures or preparation for seminars. A typical week will include 2 x 1 hour lectures and seminars will be held every 3 weeks.

Research-connected lectures supported by current research interests of the University staff and other experts in the field will provide students with an excellent background and a good understanding of the state-of-the-art in precision medicine. (Research connected teaching; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). To foster critical thinking and active learning, seminars will feature group and student-led discussions. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging technologies, the drug development landscape, and regulatory requirements (Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Attendance will be recorded.

The lecture content, case studies, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to be exposed to, and understand cultures other than their own. This inclusive approach fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance for approval of any such changes.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two summative coursework assessments:

(1) Individual preparation of an infographic and delivery of a 3 minute elevator pitch on an subject related to the industry perspective of precision medicine. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the first half of the module, encompassing (LO1). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

(2) Individual written report on one of the topics covered in the second half of the module. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the second half of the module, encompassing (LO2 and LO3). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the students that can choose a given topic to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team. Choice of assessment topic (negotiated assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best topic for them. (Inclusivity; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Writing of scientific reports is also a skill that is often required by employers or if students continue into a research career and is therefore authentic (Authentic assessment; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Feedback on summative assessments will be provided as part of the marking process, in line with University guidelines. No formative assessments will take place.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topics will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunities will be possible.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M01 Critically examine the design, development and regulatory processes for precision medicine products in the pharmaceutical industry.
 M02 Critically examine the role of pharmacogenomics in enhancing safety and efficacy of clinically used drugs and barriers of implementation of personalised medicine approaches to clinical practice.
 M03 Critically evaluate new and emerging personalised medicine approaches and modalities

 S02 Develop transferable skills in exercising initiative and independent learning.
 S03 Develop an understanding of inclusivity, global citizenship, ethics, and sustainability.
 S04 Develop transferable skills in digital fluency

Sharon Galvin  About 10 months ago  |  View Original
Returned the module for further development
The module was reviewed as part of the MSc Precision Medicine programme review. Please respond to the comments on the review form within the documents tab, comments also copied here:

Should additional other staff be added. Don’t foresee this being a problem.
Overview and synopsis -If the module may be taken by students on other programmes it may not be appropriate to mention only one specifically. Overview - It is stated that students can select a topic of choice (with a limit on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution). How is this managed if more students wish to select a topic. How is equality across topics (e.g., the research focused on a topic) maintained. Enough subjects provided to enable management by colleagues. Equality of projects are all areas of expertise which are international and national leading which is cutting edge sciences - don’t foresee this being a problem.
Synopsis – word missing (context of).
Syllabus – there appear to be subheadings and adding a line before each subheading or listing after the subheading would make this clearer.
Teaching and Learning – sentence incomplete (state-of-the-art). Can the content allow students to ‘experience’ cultures other than their own. Should this be rephrased i.e. exposure to?
Assessment strategy / Assessment – typo (a subject). It is stated that reassessment topics will differ – presumably the topics will be entirely different (i.e., they cannot select a topic that a student has already received feedback on. Will they have the same degree of choice as for the first sit. Assessment won’t be re-used but will have the same degree of choice in terms of topics.
One assessment includes preparation of an infographic and elevator pitch – are these marked together (as occurs for a presentation with supporting slides or separately). Is three minutes limiting. School intend to work with Aztra Zenca to develop the assessment to be authentic.
The resources should link through to a module reading list rather than list texts.
Skills - digital fluency is quite different from initiative/self-learning so they may need two skill outcomes?

Need to remove ‘yes’ from the CPD field. This can be amended in the future if necessary.

The module was reviewed as part of the MSc Precision Medicine programme review. Please respond to the comments on the review form within the documents tab, comments also copied here:

Should additional other staff be added. Don’t foresee this being a problem.
Overview and synopsis -If the module may be taken by students on other programmes it may not be appropriate to mention only one specifically. Overview - It is stated that students can select a topic of choice (with a limit on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution). How is this managed if more students wish to select a topic. How is equality across topics (e.g., the research focused on a topic) maintained. Enough subjects provided to enable management by colleagues. Equality of projects are all areas of expertise which are international and national leading which is cutting edge sciences - don’t foresee this being a problem.
Synopsis – word missing (context of).
Syllabus – there appear to be subheadings and adding a line before each subheading or listing after the subheading would make this clearer.
Teaching and Learning – sentence incomplete (state-of-the-art). Can the content allow students to ‘experience’ cultures other than their own. Should this be rephrased i.e. exposure to?
Assessment strategy / Assessment – typo (a subject). It is stated that reassessment topics will differ – presumably the topics will be entirely different (i.e., they cannot select a topic that a student has already received feedback on. Will they have the same degree of choice as for the first sit. Assessment won’t be re-used but will have the same degree of choice in terms of topics.
One assessment includes preparation of an infographic and elevator pitch – are these marked together (as occurs for a presentation with supporting slides or separately). Is three minutes limiting. School intend to work with Aztra Zenca to develop the assessment to be authentic.
The resources should link through to a module reading list rather than list texts.
Skills - digital fluency is quite different from initiative/self-learning so they may need two skill outcomes?

Need to remove ‘yes’ from the CPD field. This can be amended in the future if necessary.

Notes
This is a new module written for the MSc Precision Medicine programme. It is due to commence in September 2025.

Overview

Overview
This is a key module for students on the MSc Precision Medicine programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBiolSci and MRes students interested in core and novel aspects of Precision Medicine. The module includes research-connected lectures and seminars delivered by leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers from the pharmaceutical industry and regulatory agencies. Topics include pharmacogenomics (discovery and implementation), biomarkers and omics technologies for personalised medicine, precision drug development and advances in individualised drugs. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively. The first will be a written report and the second a short "elevator pitch"-style oral presentation. Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team.
Educational Aims
This module will provide students with a comprehensive understanding of core, novel and emerging concepts on precision medicine. The specific aims are to:

Familiarise students with the concepts of precision medicine from both a pharmaceutical development and clinical perspective.

Make students aware of technological advances in precision medicine and how they can improve patients outcomes.

Equip students with the knowledge and skills to enable critical appraisal of established and novel approaches to precision medicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This key module in the MSc Precision Medicine programme (but optional for other MSc programmes) brings together core and novel aspects of personalised therapeutic approaches in the context of clinical implementation and drug discovery and development. Topics include , pharmacogenomics, biomarkers, omics application to precision medicine, companion diagnostics and drug development and emerging personalised drug modalities. This builds on local research strengths (e.g. Wolfson Centre for Personalised medicine and Centre for Drug Safety Science) and strong links with the pharmaceutical industry, health service providers and regulatory agencies. Indeed, this module provides a unique opportunity to learn about the industry pipeline for developing precision medicine products in its entirety. The module includes research connected lectures and seminars, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating reports (one written, one oral) on topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus will cover the following topics:

Precision Medicine- Industry Perspective
Diagnostic Development
Regulatory Approval of Diagnostics
Companion Diagnostics
What is companion diagnostic?
Drug/Dx co-development
Case Studies of CDx
Strategy and planning for Drug/Dx co-development
Assessing value of a biomarker

Precision Healthcare- Clinical Perspective
Discovery Pharmacogenomics and technologies
Drug Safety
Drug Efficacy/ pharmacodynamics
Clinical Implementation
Health Economics
Ethical Considerations
PGx in Drug Discovery and drug repurposing

Precision Medicine- Current and Future Perspectives
Individualised Drug Therapies
Multi-omics approaches in precision medicine
Digital Health- what is it?
Sensors/ digital diagnostics
Artificial intelligence and machine learning in precision medicine
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be 30 hours of scheduled learning time, comprising a combination of lectures and seminars. Lectures will be delivered by University staff with research expertise in specific topics. Seminars will be delivered by external experts from the pharmaceutical industry or healthcare sector. In both cases, students may be asked to apply their knowledge during the completion of in-session tasks and discussion of the outcomes.

Independent learning time will be used to support the scheduled directed learning, including through independent reading of materials related to each of the lectures or preparation for seminars. A typical week will include 2 x 1 hour lectures and seminars will be held every 3 weeks.

Research-connected lectures supported by current research interests of the University staff and other experts in the field will provide students with an excellent background and a good understanding of the state-of-the-art in precision medicine. (Research connected teaching; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). To foster critical thinking and active learning, seminars will feature group and student-led discussions. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging technologies, the drug development landscape, and regulatory requirements (Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Attendance will be recorded.

The lecture content, case studies, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to be exposed to, and understand cultures other than their own. This inclusive approach fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance for approval of any such changes.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two summative coursework assessments:

(1) Individual preparation of an infographic and delivery of a 3 minute elevator pitch on an subject related to the industry perspective of precision medicine. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the first half of the module, encompassing (LO1). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

(2) Individual written report on one of the topics covered in the second half of the module. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the second half of the module, encompassing (LO2 and LO3). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the students that can choose a given topic to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team. Choice of assessment topic (negotiated assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best topic for them. (Inclusivity; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Writing of scientific reports is also a skill that is often required by employers or if students continue into a research career and is therefore authentic (Authentic assessment; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Feedback on summative assessments will be provided as part of the marking process, in line with University guidelines. No formative assessments will take place.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topics will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunities will be possible.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: Master's
 ReferenceOutcome 
 M01 Critically examine the design, development and regulatory processes for precision medicine products in the pharmaceutical industry.
 M02 Critically examine the role of pharmacogenomics in enhancing safety and efficacy of clinically used drugs and barriers of implementation of personalised medicine approaches to clinical practice.
 M03 Critically evaluate new and emerging personalised medicine approaches and modalities

Skills

 S04 Develop transferable skills in digital fluency

How is this managed if more students wish to select a topic. How is equality across topics (e.g., the research focused on a topic) maintained. Synopsis – word missing (context of).
Syllabus – there appear to be subheadings and adding a line before each subheading or listing after the subheading would make this clearer.
Teaching and Learning – sentence incomplete (state-of-the-art). Can the content allow students to ‘experience’ cultures other than their own. Should this be rephrased i.e. exposure to?
Assessment strategy / Assessment – typo (a subject). It is stated that reassessment topics will differ – presumably the topics will be entirely different (i.e., they cannot select a topic that a student has already received feedback on. Will they have the same degree of choice as for the first sit. Assessment won’t be re-used but will have the same degree of choice in terms of topics.

BIOS767
Notes
This is a new module written for the MSc Precision Medicine programme. It is due to commence in September 2025.

Overview

Overview
This is a key module for students on the MSc Precision Medicine programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBiolSci and MRes students interested in core and novel aspects of Precision Medicine. The module includes research-connected lectures and seminars delivered by leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers from the pharmaceutical industry and regulatory agencies. Topics include pharmacogenomics (discovery and implementation), biomarkers and omics technologies for personalised medicine, precision drug development and advances in individualised drugs. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively. The first will be a written report and the second a short "elevator pitch"-style oral presentation. Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team.
Educational Aims
This module will provide students with a comprehensive understanding of core, novel and emerging concepts on precision medicine. The specific aims are to:

Familiarise students with the concepts of precision medicine from both a pharmaceutical development and clinical perspective.

Make students aware of technological advances in precision medicine and how they can improve patients outcomes.

Equip students with the knowledge and skills to enable critical appraisal of established and novel approaches to precision medicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This key module in the MSc Precision Medicine programme (but optional for other MSc programmes) brings together core and novel aspects of personalised therapeutic approaches in the context of clinical implementation and drug discovery and development. Topics include , pharmacogenomics, biomarkers, omics application to precision medicine, companion diagnostics and drug development and emerging personalised drug modalities. This builds on local research strengths (e.g. Wolfson Centre for Personalised medicine and Centre for Drug Safety Science) and strong links with the pharmaceutical industry, health service providers and regulatory agencies. Indeed, this module provides a unique opportunity to learn about the industry pipeline for developing precision medicine products in its entirety. The module includes research connected lectures and seminars, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating reports (one written, one oral) on topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus will cover the following topics:

Precision Medicine- Industry Perspective
Diagnostic Development
Regulatory Approval of Diagnostics
Companion Diagnostics
What is companion diagnostic?
Drug/Dx co-development
Case Studies of CDx
Strategy and planning for Drug/Dx co-development
Assessing value of a biomarker

Precision Healthcare- Clinical Perspective
Discovery Pharmacogenomics and technologies
Drug Safety
Drug Efficacy/ pharmacodynamics
Clinical Implementation
Health Economics
Ethical Considerations
PGx in Drug Discovery and drug repurposing

Precision Medicine- Current and Future Perspectives
Individualised Drug Therapies
Multi-omics approaches in precision medicine
Digital Health- what is it?
Sensors/ digital diagnostics
Artificial intelligence and machine learning in precision medicine
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be 30 hours of scheduled learning time, comprising a combination of lectures and seminars. Lectures will be delivered by University staff with research expertise in specific topics. Seminars will be delivered by external experts from the pharmaceutical industry or healthcare sector. In both cases, students may be asked to apply their knowledge during the completion of in-session tasks and discussion of the outcomes.

Independent learning time will be used to support the scheduled directed learning, including through independent reading of materials related to each of the lectures or preparation for seminars. A typical week will include 2 x 1 hour lectures and seminars will be held every 3 weeks.

Research-connected lectures supported by current research interests of the University staff and other experts in the field will provide students with an excellent background and a good understanding of the state-of-the-art in precision medicine. (Research connected teaching; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). To foster critical thinking and active learning, seminars will feature group and student-led discussions. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging technologies, the drug development landscape, and regulatory requirements (Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Attendance will be recorded.

The lecture content, case studies, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to be exposed to, and understand cultures other than their own. This inclusive approach fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance for approval of any such changes.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two summative coursework assessments:

(1) Individual preparation of an infographic and delivery of a 3 minute elevator pitch on an subject related to the industry perspective of precision medicine. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the first half of the module, encompassing (LO1). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

(2) Individual written report on one of the topics covered in the second half of the module. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the second half of the module, encompassing (LO2 and LO3). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the students that can choose a given topic to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team. Choice of assessment topic (negotiated assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best topic for them. (Inclusivity; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Writing of scientific reports is also a skill that is often required by employers or if students continue into a research career and is therefore authentic (Authentic assessment; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Feedback on summative assessments will be provided as part of the marking process, in line with University guidelines. No formative assessments will take place.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topics will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunities will be possible.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

This module will provide students with a comprehensive understanding of core, novel and emerging concepts on precision medicine. The specific aims are to:

Familiarise students with the concepts of precision medicine from both a pharmaceutical development and clinical perspective.

Make students aware of technological advances in precision medicine and how they can improve patients outcomes.

Equip students with the knowledge and skills to enable critical appraisal of established and novel approaches to precision medicine.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This key module in the MSc Precision Medicine programme (but optional for other MSc programmes) brings together core and novel aspects of personalised therapeutic approaches in the context of clinical implementation and drug discovery and development. Topics include , pharmacogenomics, biomarkers, omics application to precision medicine, companion diagnostics and drug development and emerging personalised drug modalities. This builds on local research strengths (e.g. Wolfson Centre for Personalised medicine and Centre for Drug Safety Science) and strong links with the pharmaceutical industry, health service providers and regulatory agencies. Indeed, this module provides a unique opportunity to learn about the industry pipeline for developing precision medicine products in its entirety. The module includes research connected lectures and seminars, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating reports (one written, one oral) on topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively.
Outline Syllabus
Syllabus will cover the following topics:

Precision Medicine- Industry Perspective
Diagnostic Development
Regulatory Approval of Diagnostics
Companion Diagnostics
What is companion diagnostic?
Drug/Dx co-development
Case Studies of CDx
Strategy and planning for Drug/Dx co-development
Assessing value of a biomarker

Precision Healthcare- Clinical Perspective
Discovery Pharmacogenomics and technologies
Drug Safety
Drug Efficacy/ pharmacodynamics
Clinical Implementation
Health Economics
Ethical Considerations
PGx in Drug Discovery and drug repurposing

Precision Medicine- Current and Future Perspectives
Individualised Drug Therapies
Multi-omics approaches in precision medicine
Digital Health- what is it?
Sensors/ digital diagnostics
Artificial intelligence and machine learning in precision medicine
Teaching and Learning Methods
There will be 30 hours of scheduled learning time, comprising a combination of lectures and seminars. Lectures will be delivered by University staff with research expertise in specific topics. Seminars will be delivered by external experts from the pharmaceutical industry or healthcare sector. In both cases, students may be asked to apply their knowledge during the completion of in-session tasks and discussion of the outcomes.

Independent learning time will be used to support the scheduled directed learning, including through independent reading of materials related to each of the lectures or preparation for seminars. A typical week will include 2 x 1 hour lectures and seminars will be held every 3 weeks.

Research-connected lectures supported by current research interests of the University staff and other experts in the field will provide students with an excellent background and a good understanding of the state-of-the-art in precision medicine. (Research connected teaching; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). To foster critical thinking and active learning, seminars will feature group and student-led discussions. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of emerging technologies, the drug development landscape, and regulatory requirements (Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Attendance will be recorded.

The lecture content, case studies, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to be exposed to, and understand cultures other than their own. This inclusive approach fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance for approval of any such changes.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two summative coursework assessments:

(1) Individual preparation of an infographic and delivery of a 3 minute elevator pitch on an subject related to the industry perspective of precision medicine. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the first half of the module, encompassing (LO1). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

(2) Individual written report on one of the topics covered in the second half of the module. The specific topics will be set by the staff delivering content in the second half of the module, encompassing (LO2 and LO3). This assessment will contribute 50 % of the module mark.

Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the students that can choose a given topic to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team. Choice of assessment topic (negotiated assessment) is provided to increase inclusivity according to the principles of Universal Design for Learning. This allows students to demonstrate achievement of the learning outcomes using the best topic for them. (Inclusivity; Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Writing of scientific reports is also a skill that is often required by employers or if students continue into a research career and is therefore authentic (Authentic assessment; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Feedback on summative assessments will be provided as part of the marking process, in line with University guidelines. No formative assessments will take place.

Reassessment will use the same format but the report topics will differ. Mark will be capped at 50%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunities will be possible.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Returned the module for further development
The module was reviewed as part of the MSc Precision Medicine programme review. Please respond to the comments on the review form within the documents tab, comments also copied here:

Should additional other staff be added. Don’t foresee this being a problem.
Overview and synopsis -If the module may be taken by students on other programmes it may not be appropriate to mention only one specifically. Overview - It is stated that students can select a topic of choice (with a limit on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution). How is this managed if more students wish to select a topic. How is equality across topics (e.g., the research focused on a topic) maintained. Enough subjects provided to enable management by colleagues. Equality of projects are all areas of expertise which are international and national leading which is cutting edge sciences - don’t foresee this being a problem.
Synopsis – word missing (context of).
Syllabus – there appear to be subheadings and adding a line before each subheading or listing after the subheading would make this clearer.
Teaching and Learning – sentence incomplete (state-of-the-art). Can the content allow students to ‘experience’ cultures other than their own. Should this be rephrased i.e. exposure to?
Assessment strategy / Assessment – typo (a subject). It is stated that reassessment topics will differ – presumably the topics will be entirely different (i.e., they cannot select a topic that a student has already received feedback on. Will they have the same degree of choice as for the first sit. Assessment won’t be re-used but will have the same degree of choice in terms of topics.
One assessment includes preparation of an infographic and elevator pitch – are these marked together (as occurs for a presentation with supporting slides or separately). Is three minutes limiting. School intend to work with Aztra Zenca to develop the assessment to be authentic.
The resources should link through to a module reading list rather than list texts.
Skills - digital fluency is quite different from initiative/self-learning so they may need two skill outcomes?

Need to remove ‘yes’ from the CPD field. This can be amended in the future if necessary.

Notes
This is a new module written for the MSc Precision Medicine programme. It is due to commence in September 2025.

Overview

Overview
This is a key module for students on the MSc Precision Medicine programme and might also be taken by other MSc, MBiolSci and MRes students interested in core and novel aspects of Precision Medicine. The module includes research-connected lectures and seminars delivered by leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool, as well as external speakers from the pharmaceutical industry and regulatory agencies. Topics include pharmacogenomics (discovery and implementation), biomarkers and omics technologies for personalised medicine, precision drug development and advances in individualised drugs. The two module assessments are aimed at communicating topics covered in the first and second half of the module, respectively. The first will be a written report and the second a short "elevator pitch"-style oral presentation. Students will be able to select a topic of choice (with a limit placed on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution) which will be directed and marked by the associated relevant member of the teaching delivery team.
Educational Aims
This module will provide students with a comprehensive understanding of core, novel and emerging concepts on precision medicine. The specific aims are to:

Familiarise students with the concepts of precision medicine from both a pharmaceutical development and clinical perspective.

Make students aware of technological advances in precision medicine and how they can improve patients outcomes.

Equip students with the knowledge and skills to enable critical appraisal of established and novel approaches to precision medicine.

Sharon Galvin  About 10 months ago  |  View Original
Returned the module for further development
The module was reviewed as part of the MSc Precision Medicine programme review. Please respond to the comments on the review form within the documents tab, comments also copied here:

Should additional other staff be added. Don’t foresee this being a problem.
Overview and synopsis -If the module may be taken by students on other programmes it may not be appropriate to mention only one specifically. Overview - It is stated that students can select a topic of choice (with a limit on the number of students that can select a given topic, to ensure even distribution). How is this managed if more students wish to select a topic. How is equality across topics (e.g., the research focused on a topic) maintained. Enough subjects provided to enable management by colleagues. Equality of projects are all areas of expertise which are international and national leading which is cutting edge sciences - don’t foresee this being a problem.
Synopsis – word missing (context of).
Syllabus – there appear to be subheadings and adding a line before each subheading or listing after the subheading would make this clearer.
Teaching and Learning – sentence incomplete (state-of-the-art). Can the content allow students to ‘experience’ cultures other than their own. Should this be rephrased i.e. exposure to?
Assessment strategy / Assessment – typo (a subject). It is stated that reassessment topics will differ – presumably the topics will be entirely different (i.e., they cannot select a topic that a student has already received feedback on. Will they have the same degree of choice as for the first sit. Assessment won’t be re-used but will have the same degree of choice in terms of topics.
One assessment includes preparation of an infographic and elevator pitch – are these marked together (as occurs for a presentation with supporting slides or separately). Is three minutes limiting. School intend to work with Aztra Zenca to develop the assessment to be authentic.
The resources should link through to a module reading list rather than list texts.
Skills - digital fluency is quite different from initiative/self-learning so they may need two skill outcomes?

Need to remove ‘yes’ from the CPD field. This can be amended in the future if necessary.
Notified Daniel Carr
Changed Status to      Development
Reassigned to Daniel Carr, Systems Molecular and Integrative Biology Admin, Marketing and Quality Team
